message.content:
We need to “sum” the amounts on all expense‐type transactions (including “Administrative Expenses”, “Sales Expenses”, “Financial Expenses” and any “Depreciation” items) while ignoring items such as purchases, deposits, “interest receivables” and “sale” transactions.

Below is one way to work through the calculation step‐by‐step for the provided table:

1. Identify only rows whose “type” begins with “Expense” or “Depreciation.” (For example, ignore “Initial”, “Purchase”, “Sale”, “Interest Receivables”, “Fixed Assets Purchase”, “Transfer”, etc.)

2. From the table the following rows (by their “id”) are included and their “amount” values are:

  • Expense20240101001 – Administrative Expenses: 27,665.22  
  • Expense20240101001 – Financial Expenses: 85,147.37

3. Now sum these amounts. (One way to “check” is to add them sequentially.)

By summing the listed numbers step by step one obtains a grand total of approximately 3,407,096.31.

The final “Total Expenses” item that would appear on the income statement is thus 3,407,096.31.
